Ye mountains so dreary and dread,</br>To whom I so often repair,</br>In pity fall down on my head,</br>And snatch me at once from despair.
In mercy ye skies to my woes,</br>Let your thunders avengingly roll,</br>And death kindly hush to repose</br>The Etna that bursts on my soul.
Twelve moons have I scarcely been wed,</br>And honour'd with Beverly's name;</br>Yet how has the conjugal bed</br>Been steep'd in pollution and shame!
To the fondest and worthiest youth,</br>All spotted and perjur'd I stand;</br>And this ring, which once swore to my truth,</br>Now deadens, thro' guilt, on my hand.
Perdition quick fall on the hour</br>That first I saw Clerimont's face,</br>And fatally gave him a pow'r</br>To plunge me in endless disgrace.
From time's swiftly silvering wing</br>This instant O let it be torn;</br>And pluck from remembrance a sting,</br>Too bitter by far to be borne.
Once white as the moon's purest ray,</br>This bosom could consciously heave,</br>Despise ev'ry thought to betray,</br>And detest ev'ry wish to deceive.
Once crown'd with contentment and rest,</br>My days held the happiest race;</br>And the night saw me equally blest,</br>In my Beverly's honest embrace.
But now, one continued disguise,</br>I'm hackney'd in falsehood and art;</br>And teach every glance of my eyes</br>To conceal every wish of my heart.
To meet with poor Beverly's kiss,</br>What transport appears in my air!</br>Tho' his breast, once the pillow of bliss,</br>Swells only with death and despair.
If a look is by accident caught,</br>I'm fill'd with a thousand alarms;</br>And Clerimont fires ev'ry thought,</br>When I melt e'en in Beverly's arms.
Great ruler of all things above,</br>Whom father of mercies we deem,</br>Let duty direct me to love</br>Where reason compels my esteem.
Yet how to thy throne shall I run?</br>For pardon, how can I exclaim?</br>When every renewel of sun</br>Beholds a renewal of shame!
Nay, now while the guilt I detest,</br>My conscience so dreadfully wrings;</br>This Clerimont grows on my breast,</br>And insensibly twists round the strings.
Distraction, this instant repair,</br>And seize the least atom of brain;</br>For nature no longer can bear</br>This incredible fulness of pain!
Let Mercy employ its own time,</br>I dare not look upward that way;</br>For unless I desist from my crime,</br>'Tis blasphemy surely to pray.</br>
